   Melvin Sickler
   stated on March 14, 2013 in a U.S. Senate hearing :
   Says Oregon’s high minimum wage is the reason why "by 2011, Oregon's
   restaurants employed an average of only 13.8 workers, or 2.6 fewer
   employees than they did before the state's minimum wage began rising above
   the federal level in 1997."

After peaking at 16.4 employees per establishment in 1996, the average
   number of workers in Oregon's restaurants declined steadily."

"By 2011, Oregon's restaurants employed an average of only 13.8 workers,
   or 2.6 fewer employees than they did before the state's minimum wage began
   rising above the federal level in 1997," he said.

true true
